facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 21, 1952, of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated August 29, 1950, of the Court of District Judge of Zillah Burdwan in Title Appeal No. 247/16 of 1948

facts.text: Additional Sub-Judge, 1st Court, Burdwan judgment dated September 25, 1948 in Title Suit No. 7 of 1946/27 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: against judgment and decree dated September 25, 1948, of the Court of Additional Sub-Judge, 1st Court, Burdwan, in Title Suit No. 7 of 1946/27 of 1947.

facts.text: Suit property is a Mahal of 84 Bighas 18 Cottas in lot Ahiyapur village, Burdwan Zamindari.

anchor.surface_text: The suit property is a Mahal of the extent of 84 Bighas 18 Cottas situated within lot Ahiyapur village, which is one of the villages forming part of the permanently settled estate of Burdwan Zamindari.

facts.text: Village granted in Patni settlement to predecessors-in-title of defendants 1 to 7 prior to Bengal Regulation VIII of 1819.

anchor.surface_text: This village was granted by the Maharaja of Burdwan in Patni settlement to the predecessors- in-title of defendants I to 7. The exact date of this grant does number appear,

facts.text: Mahal set apart as Chaukidari Chakaran lands prior to permanent settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The Mahal with which this litigation is companycerned, had been at or prior to the permanent settlement set apart as Chaukidari Chakaran lands that is to say,

facts.text: Village Chaukidari Act, 1870 (Ben. VI of 1870) passed, s.48 transferred Chaukidari lands to zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: In 1870, the Village Chaukidari Act, 1870  Ben. VI of 1870 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, was passed, and s. 48 of that Act provides that all Chaukidari Chakaran lands

facts.text: Suit properties transferred to Maharaja of Burdwan.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the provisions aforesaid, the suit properties were transferred to the Maharaja of Burdwan,

facts.text: On June 3, 1899, Maharaja granted suit lands to predecessors of defendants 1-7 under Exhibit B at Rs. 126-8 as. yearly rental.

anchor.surface_text: and on June 3,1899, he granted the same to the predecessors-in- title of defendants I to 7, who at that time held the Patni interest in respect of lot Ahiyapur. Under the grant which has been marked as exhibit B,

facts.text: Maharaja applied under s.8 Regulation VIII 1819, auction on May 15, 1937, purchased himself.

anchor.surface_text: Acting under this clause, the Maharaja applied under s. 8 of the Regulation to bring the suit lands to sale for realisation of arrears, and at the auction held on May 15, 1937, himself became the purchaser.

facts.text: On February 13, 1941, Maharaja granted lands to appellant/plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: On February 13, 1941, he granted the lands again on Patni to the appellant, who filed the suit, out of which the present appeal arises,

facts.text: Plaintiff filed suit for ejectment alleging trespass by defendants.

anchor.surface_text: in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Burdwan, to recover possession thereof from the defendants alleging that they had trespassed thereon.

facts.text: Defendants contested suit claiming no arrears of rent under Exhibit B, sale void.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companytested the suit on the ground that, in fact, there were numberarrears of rent due under Exhibit B, and that the sale was therefore void.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held arrears due and s.14 bar applies, decreed for plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that there were arrears of rent due from the respondents, and that further as they had number sued to set aside the sale under s. 14 of the Regulation within the time limited by law,

facts.text: District Judge dismissed appeal, held Exhibit B new Patni, s.14 bar.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge after observing that the point was taken for the first time, held on a companystruction of Exhibit B that it created a new Patni, and that it companyld therefore be brought to sale,

facts.text: Calcutta High Court (Das Gupta and Lahiri JJ) allowed second appeal, held Exhibit B incorporates lands into lot Ahiyapur Patni, sale void.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents took the matter in second appeal to the High Court, and that was heard by a Bench companysisting of Das Gupta and Lahiri JJ. who differed from the District Judge both on the companystruction of Exhibit B

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Exhibit B created a new distinct Patni.

anchor.surface_text: Construing Exhibit B, as a whole, we are of opinion that the intention of the parties as expressed therein was that the Chaukidari Chakaran lands should be held as a distinct Patni.

facts.text: Defendants did not raise plea in trial court that Exhibit B made lands part of lot Ahiyapur Patni.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant urged the following companytentions in support of the appeal  1  The defendants did number raise either in the written statement or during the trial,

facts.text: Supreme Court rejects contention that point could not be raised in appeal, as question of law.

anchor.surface_text: Under the circumstances, the learned Judges were right in allowing this point to be taken. This companytention must therefore be rejected.

facts.text: Sale of lands under Exhibit B valid as new Patni.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Exhibit B created a new Patni and that the sale of the lands companyprised therein is number bad as of a portion of a, Patni.

anchor.surface_text: This contention must therefore be rejected. The next point for determination is as to the true character of the grant under Exhibit B, whether it amounts to a new Patni with reference to the Chaukidari Chakaran lands as contended for by the appellant, or whether it incorporates those lands in the Patni of lot Ahiyapur, so as to make them part and parcel of the lands comprised therein, as is maintained by the respondents.

holdings.text: Now, when s. 51 of the Act recognises and saves rights which had been acquired under contract with the Zamindar, its reasonable implication is that the rights so recognised are the same as under the contract, and that, in consequence, the settlement of the Chaukidari Chakaran lands in Patni must be taken to be a continuance of the Patni of the village in which they are included. But it is open to the parties to agree that the Chaukidari Chakaran lands should form a new and distinct Patni

precedents.cited_proposition: in construction of deed, if earlier clause followed by later repugnant clause, earlier prevails
